captions.text: Water is the liquid of life.
It's the most abundant molecule in our bodies.
In fact, every life form we know of
Why do these ice cubes float?
If these were cubes of solid argon
in a cup of liquid argon,
And the same goes for most other substances.
is somehow less dense than liquid water.
You already know that every water molecule
is made up of two hydrogen atoms
Let's look at a few of the molecules
and let's say the temperature is 25 degrees Celcius.
which will reduce the amount of kinetic energy
so they'll bend, stretch, spin, and move less.
And that means that on average,
Now, you'd think that as the liquid water
the molecules would just pack together
that most other substances don't have,
and it's called a hydrogen bond.
Now, remember that in a covalent bond
a hydrogen atom is shared, also unequally,
One hydrogen bond looks like this.
In a single drop of water,
and these bonds are constantly breaking and reforming.
Now, back to our water as it cools down.
the kinetic energy of the water molecules
keeps their interactions with each other short.
the kinetic energy of the water molecules
starts to fall below the energy
So, hydrogen bonds form much more frequently
and beautiful structures start to emerge
This is what solid water, ice,
looks like on the molecular level.
Notice that the ordered, hexagonal structure
is less dense than the disordered structure
And you know that if an object is less dense
Well, let's consider a world without floating ice.
The coldest part of the ocean
would be the pitch-black ocean floor,
since crustaceans would lose their habitats,
or sushi since kelp forests wouldn't grow.
What would Canadian kids do in winter
without pond hockey or ice fishing?
because the Titanic totally would have made it.
Say goodbye to the white polar ice caps
that would otherwise bake the planet.
In fact, forget the oceans as we know them,
which at over 70% of the Earth's surface area,
regulate the atmosphere of the whole planet.
there would be no iced tea.

comments.text:
Also interesting: Suppose an ice cube floats in a glass of water.  As the 
ice melts, the level of the water does not change.  One might ponder how 
this figures into Global Warming and rising ocean levels.﻿
comments.author: trukkstop1

comments.text:
+tpespos That's incorrect, or I'm misunderstanding you. The cause of rising 
sea levels is ice on land melting. There is no change in water level when 
you have a suspended piece of ice that melts, because the portion of ice in 
the water occupies the same volume as the entire piece of ice if it were 
melted.
comments.author: HydrixCooper

comments.text:
Well it has to do with the ice above the water because the ice above is not 
displacing the water below even though melting it would make it denser 
(less volume of same mass) the ice above would melt and all of that melted 
ice above the water then gets added to the water creating higher ocean 
there is a lot more to the global warming issue

comments.author: SoulAsasin Jr.

comments.text:
That John Shrader fellow is right for the most part, however, he says that 
"when hydrogen get colder they start sharing hydrogen bonds". This is true 
but they always share hydrogen bonds, whether the water is cold or not. The 
difference is the rate at which the hydrogen bonds are broken. When at 
warmer temperatures they break and reform at a rapid pace and at colder 
temperatures there is more forming and less breaking, giving the crystal 
structure.﻿

comments.author: Chris Illssbilsworth

comments.text:
They did answer. When most molecules get colder, they get closer together 
(implying that they get further apart when they are heated). As they pack 
together they get denser and thus would sink. But water, as per the video, 
has hydrogen bonds. When water gets colder they start sharing hydrogen 
atoms, forming structures. When they get warmer the hydrogen bonds form and 
break up frequently. Because of the bonds at the colder end, they take up 
less space, thus floats. All of this was in the video.
